[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: new()] [Initialization vulnerability] Can an attacker construct a StandardGasMeter with a malicious algebra implementation that bypasses gas charging, allowing unlimited computation and causing validator DoS? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: feature_version()] [Version bypass] Can feature_version() be manipulated to return inconsistent values across validators, causing non-deterministic gas calculations and state divergence leading to consensus failure? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: charge_dependency()] [Special address bypass] In the special address check at line 70, can an attacker craft transactions loading modules from addresses that satisfy is_special() to avoid dependency gas charges, enabling unlimited module loading and memory exhaustion? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: charge_dependency()] [Feature version manipulation] Can an attacker exploit the feature_version() >= 15 check to load dependencies with zero gas cost by downgrading feature versions, allowing DoS through excessive module dependencies? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: charge_dependency()] [Integer overflow] Can the calculation DEPENDENCY_PER_MODULE + DEPENDENCY_PER_BYTE * size overflow when size is extremely large, wrapping to a small value and allowing massive dependencies with minimal gas? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: charge_dependency()] [Legacy address exploit] The TODO comment mentions 0xA550C18 as a legacy system address not covered by is_special() - can an attacker abuse this address to load unlimited modules without gas charges? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: charge_dependency()] [Count bypass] Does count_dependency() properly track dependency sizes, or can an attacker exploit it to manipulate dependency accounting and bypass limits? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: charge_dependency()] [Determinism violation] Are dependency gas calculations deterministic across all validators regardless of module loading order, or can race conditions cause different gas consumption and state divergence? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: legacy_gas_budget_in_native_context()] [Balance manipulation] Can an attacker manipulate the internal gas balance returned by balance_internal() to receive inflated gas budgets in native functions, allowing excessive computation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: charge_native_execution()] [Gas bypass] Can native functions charge arbitrary amounts including negative values to refund gas, potentially leading to infinite gas and validator DoS? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: use_heap_memory_in_native_context()] [Memory exhaustion] This function always returns Ok(()) without charging - can an attacker exploit this to allocate unlimited heap memory in native functions causing validator crashes? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: charge_native_function_before_execution()] [Pre-execution bypass] This function returns Ok(()) without any gas charging - can attackers exploit this to execute expensive native function setup logic for free? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: charge_native_function()] [TODO exploitation] The TODO comment questions if charging is correct - can an attacker exploit incorrect native function gas metering to underpay for expensive operations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: charge_native_function()] [Return value bypass] The _ret_vals parameter is ignored - can attackers return massive data structures from native functions without paying gas for serialization costs? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: charge_br_false()] [Target offset bypass] The _target_offset parameter is unused - can an attacker exploit long-distance branches that should cost more gas but are charged uniformly? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: charge_br_true()] [Conditional exploitation] Are BR_TRUE and BR_FALSE costs identical, or can attackers craft bytecode with predictable branches to optimize gas usage unfairly? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: charge_branch()] [Unconditional branch abuse] Can attackers create infinite loops with BRANCH instructions consuming minimal gas, exhausting execution time without paying proportional gas? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: charge_simple_instr()] [Macro dispatch vulnerability] Can an attacker exploit the macro dispatch mechanism to execute unpriced instructions or bypass gas metering entirely? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: charge_simple_instr()] [Arithmetic overflow] Do arithmetic instructions (ADD, SUB, MUL, DIV, MOD) check for overflow conditions that could consume excessive CPU time but are charged fixed gas? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: charge_simple_instr()] [U256 exploitation] Are U256 operations (LD_U256, CAST_U256) priced appropriately, or can attackers perform expensive 256-bit arithmetic for the same cost as 8-bit operations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: charge_simple_instr()] [Division by zero] Does DIV and MOD_ charging account for division by zero exceptions that trigger expensive error handling but are charged minimal gas? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: charge_simple_instr()] [Variant field operations] Are variant field operations (IMM_BORROW_VARIANT_FIELD, MUT_BORROW_VARIANT_FIELD, etc.) properly priced for enum complexity? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: charge_load_resource()] [Legacy version exploit] Can an attacker exploit the feature_version() <= 8 special case to load non-existent resources with non-zero bytes_loaded, violating invariants and causing crashes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: charge_load_resource()] [Bytes loaded manipulation] Can an attacker manipulate bytes_loaded to be much larger than the actual resource size, overpaying gas to fill validator memory with receipts and causing memory exhaustion? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-gas-meter/src/meter.rs] [Function: charge_load_resource()] [TODO correctness] The TODO comment questions correctness - can incorrect read gas calculation allow underpricing of expensive storage reads, enabling state bloat attacks? (High)
